segments.text: Okay.

They said, well, we know your circumstances, and we've had people from our company here before that have been in the same can groups with military, and we know that you only get a small per diem, which can't possibly take care of all your living expenses, and it will really be a financial burden to you unless you're a wealthy man independently for you and your family for you to be here.
And he said, we want to tell you something.
We don't want you to ever try to pick up a check when we go out to eat.
And we want to pay your phone bill.
It'll be divided up between all of us and put on our expense accounts, which are unlimited.
And any other expenses you have, we want to pay for.
And I said, for Christ's sake, what do you think I am?
I said, hell, I'm not going to accept charity from you guys.
Sure, it might be a little bit of a financial burden to me, but I'm just not going to do it.
And I said, I couldn't let you pay my phone bill and my laundry bill.
You want to pay my laundry bill, too, see?
Send out your clothes, shirts, and everything.
So they said, well, why don't you just let us do what we can then, and you keep your self-respect, if you call it that.
But we really said it's done.
It's been done for years.
And the president of my company, this was Ed Donnelly saying it, he said the president of my company, when he was up here six years ago, he said they did it.
He told me just before I left, he said, now, if there are any military in your can groups,
put their expenses on your tab.
And so I couldn't wait to get to the other military guys.
They said, yeah, we've had a meeting just like it.
And most of them took the same attitude I did.
But they did pay a lot of my expenses.
And a couple of times, I just damn near fought them over picking up checks.
So it did cost me, oh, I guess maybe $1,500, $1,600.
But nevertheless, they helped quite a bit.
Oh, yeah.
Now, why do you think they do that?

I think they do it because it's a genuine feeling of, I don't know whether it's appreciation or a general feeling of wanting to be of service and help somebody from the military or from government that doesn't have the
the financial backing to really enjoy the full fruits of the endeavor.

And I don't think they want to try to gain any brownie points for their company with anybody because I've never had any dealings with any of them and didn't anticipate ever having any official dealings with any of them.
But the last, the crowning achievement of things, the last week at the AMP is called Wives Week.
And they traditionally have the wives come up
And everybody moves out of the can group to a downtown hotel.
They all book rooms, all contiguous to one another.
And all the wives are there.
The wives make some of the classes.
They have some special classes for wives, four or five hours of classes during the week.
There are three or four big parties of entertainment, and then a final big graduation banquet and party.
It's a very expensive week, the wives' week.
Air transportation up there, staying at the Ritz, our kin group stayed at the Ritz.
So we were living in Atlanta at the Third Army, and my wife came up there and left the kids.
She flew up.
So we were there at the Ritz.
We took part in everything all during the week and just had a heck of a good time.
So we were going to check out early Sunday morning to catch an early flight back to Atlanta.
And I went down about 7 o'clock to get my tab and pay my bill.
We figured we owed $200, $250.
So I went to the desk and they said, well, Colonel, we haven't got a bill for you.
I said, what the hell do you mean?
And they said, well, we just have it.
I said, you don't have a bill.
And I said, you've got to be kidding me.
And they said, no, I said, well, who paid for it?
I said, God damn it, somebody must have paid for it.
My wife and I have been here for six days.
And they said, well, you just haven't got a bill.
And so finally, the assistant manager says, look, why don't you just be a good guy and just forget about it and walk off?
And don't ask me any more questions.
He says, believe me, you haven't got a bill.
So I don't know who paid for it, or whether they divided it up on their bills or not.
And I later saw one of the other military, and he said the same thing happened to him.
No kidding.
No kidding, yeah.
Everybody from government, when they went to pay their bill for Wives Week, the hotel just said, well, you haven't got a bill.
And they couldn't even give them a copy of the bill.
They just said, you have no bill.
Isn't that something?
That's fantastic.
And I think it's still being done today.

And they're just about the same number of guys going, because I get all the news from the Harvard Business School and the AMP programs have about the same, no more, no less, same people from the military and from the Army.
And when you so-called graduate, what do they give you, a diploma that you were in this course?
Yeah, you get a diploma, a nice little diploma.
You become a member of the Harvard alumni.
I think that's how they build up their massive alumni that continually plague you for money and so forth.
But it's a real great experience.
It's a certificate then that you pass this course.
How rigorous was the course?
Pretty doggone rigorous.
We worked every night until 10 or 11 o'clock on all these case studies.
Everything was on case studies.
So usually you worked with your TAN group.
Work with your can group, yeah.
And sometime on maybe a special project, you'd work with guys from other can groups that were in your section or in the group that the professor had assigned.
But it was, and I, many times I used a lot of things I got, particularly in the labor relations.
I had this very eminent little German guy that was a professor.
And then this guy that talked about constitutional law and antitrust legislation, he was just absolutely superb.
So you thought the professors at Harvard were quite good.
Oh, yeah.
And it was many of the things that I used extensively.
I know in my command at the Defense Industrial Supply Center that just prior to my last command, in some very
tedious steel negotiations that the government was having with big steel.
While some of the things that I learned and gained and gleaned at that, uh, uh, advanced management program really were of great assistance to me.
And I, I think it's a very worthwhile thing.
It certainly, uh, but for five months we were, you know, separated from our, from the military completely and, uh,
It's looked upon very, very strongly by the military.
People kind of bow down to you when you get an appointment to go to the Harvard Business School, to the advanced management program.
And I want to talk about getting to France.
OK.

My tour of duty, I was in charge of the operations division in the G4 section of U.S. UConn, United States European Command, which was the supreme headquarters in Europe at Camp du Loge, just outside of Paris, right in the suburbs of Paris.
And the Supreme Commander at that time was General Charles Palmer, Charles D. Palmer.
And the work there was logistics, joint logistics at this high level involving a lot of contact with NATO allies and a lot of contact and activity in connection with
NATO facilities, particularly the NATO pipeline system throughout Europe.

And it's a network of pipelines in the low countries and a network of pipelines from the coast of France, across France, into West Germany, all the way to the Rhine River, so that in the event of a war, we can unload tankers on the French coast or even in the low countries and pump
jet fuel or diesel fuel or motor fuel through this pipeline network right on as far forward as the Rhine River.
And this is all underground pipeline built pipeline system in the U.S. And a beautiful setup.
We even built pipelines in Turkey.
We built NATO pipelines in Turkey, throughout Turkey, and built a few pipelines in North Africa.
short pipelines to serve the Pueblos Airport in Libya which is now turned back of course to the Libyans and I'm sure Qaddafi is using all those facilities now.
It involved a lot of travel to the Middle East and back and forth to the Middle East, inspection type travel and visiting all types of facilities like air bases and
Eastern Turkey, and checking on the support of the U.S. to our NATO allies through the aid programs and what have you.
Very, very interesting job.
And it was there in Paris that I got word that I was nominated to be a general officer.
Yeah, tell me about that.
How did that come about, and what were your feelings at the time?
Well, of course, we had known that a selection board was convening.
Everybody does that's in the zone knows that a selection board is convening to make nominees.
So I hadn't really given a whole lot of thought about it, or certainly hadn't worried about it.
And one morning, I
I was late to work.
I think it was probably the only time during the three years I was assigned there in headquarters that I didn't get into the office till about 8.30, 8.45.
Because I had just bought a French car, a little Simca, a little four-door Simca, and I had to take it by a French garage because the windshield wipers weren't working good or something.
Anyway, I took it by the garage and
They gave me a ride to the gates of Camp Delos, and I walked from the main gate into my office.
So when I got into my office, my office, there were four or five officers in there, my secretary was in there, and a couple of civilians, and I said, what the hell's going on?
And they said, well, why don't you read the message on your desk?
So there was a cable on my desk from the Edgerton General notifying me that I had been nominated by the president.
to be a general officer.
And about that time my secretary came back and he always said, General Palmer wants to see you.
He called.
As a matter of fact, she said he called 10 minutes ago and we had to tell him that you were out for a moment.
So I said, well, I guess I better go in to see the old man.
So I went down right away and was ushered right in.
And he congratulated me and told me to sit down.
And he talked a little bit, and then I told him, and tried to be as humble as I could, that there's certainly a lot of more people more worthy and deserving than me that should have been selected.
While I'm very honored, I know that there's a hell of a lot of people that deserve it more than I did.
He looked at me and he said, look, he said, it's nice of you to say that.
But just remember this.
God damn it, they had the same chance you had.
And I've always remembered that.
And he looked me right in the eye, and he said it very sincerely.
And I really appreciated it.
He was a very, very great guy, a nice guy.
Not a household word.
He had a brother that also was a four-star general.
the two Palmer brothers, Charlie Palmer and his brother, a little short fella.
I forget what his first name was.
But both of them were really outstanding officers.
Both of them had big, had high combat commands during the war, division commanders or corps commanders.
And very capable administrators, both of them.
And he was very, he was very, very

really really meant a lot to me and for him to say all the things that he did say and immediately after that why he must have directed that they start to uh you know give me all the privileges and everything of the flag even though it was oh hell it was about seven months six months before i got my star because of the vacancies they have to wait until somebody retired and so forth and then there was some hitch came up

some congressman some senator on the armed service committee wanted to charge some general officer spots in the national guard division to the regular general officer roster and that delayed it another month or two because they they tagged the three or four spaces in the in the national guard division to the general to the general officer roster of the regular army well anyway uh us ucom

I already had a staff card that I, that was my own, that was assigned to me from my job, but about two weeks later I got a new one, a little bit, you know, a brand new one, without even asking for it, and the other one I had was perfectly good.
And it was just a lot of little things like that.
It was so obvious.
But it was, it was very good, and I stayed there for about,
90 days.
And then I was transferred back to the States to help put together the Defense Supply Agency, which was this new joint agency that Secretary McNamara had decreed that he wanted done.
Okay, but before we get to that, let's
Let's talk about France leaving or kicking the United States out of their country early in the 1960s.
Were you there at that time?
No, I was not there at that time, but I made a trip over there.
Okay.
A couple of trips over there, and we had to, I first went into Germany, and we had to get into civilian clothes before we went on into France.
No kidding.
No kidding.
They told me when I got to France.
What were your feelings about that?

Well, I just thought it was awful that I couldn't, as an American officer, and I was already a general, and that I couldn't, as an American general, get off of the airplane at Orly Field, a military airplane at Orly Field, and go into Paris in my uniform.
That I had to wear civilian clothes.
And it's the honest to God's truth.
Well, what were most of the feelings of the American officers?
Well, they were the same.
They were the same.
And it was awful.
The French people, per se, of course, nobody knew who you were.
You're walking down the street in civilian clothes.
That's fine.
But the people you had contact with, they didn't have any big change of heart to you outwardly or to your face.
They didn't say you were a no-good and so forth.
But...
You really, it was kind of a bitter pill, really.
And the French have not done a very good job on this, to jump ahead a few years, this survey I made for the Department of Defense of the pipeline.
See, when the French kicked us out, instead of us having U.S. personnel along the pipeline through France, the French now run it with a contractor
civilian contractor.
There's no U.S. military on the pipeline at all.
And when I saw it about four years ago, it was pitiful.
I'd say, I've got it in my report, but about 30% of the pumping units are inoperable.
They've been robbed of spare parts to keep some of the other ones going.
They're just like what we call hangar queens, airplanes that have been robbed of spare parts to keep other airplanes flying.
You've got an airplane in a hangar that won't fly because some wings have been taken off or ailerons have been taken off.
Why don't they order parts from American companies?
I don't know.
But rather than spend the money, they just cannibalize spare engines and spare pumps and compressors in the pump stations.
Two or three pump stations that I visited along the line were absolutely inoperable.
And the product that goes through the line is only a very small amount that they keep pumping through the line.
This is some of our product that is unloaded and pumped all through the line into Germany just to make the line operational.
It loses capacity and loses fluid velocity and everything because this pump station is inoperable to keep it moving.
limps along at a very slow pace, so the throughput in the line is greatly reduced.
And the maintenance of the thing is just awful.
The stations, the weeds are growing up around them, the paint is peeling off the wall.
It just makes you sick.
Because American money, taxpayer money, built that goddamn system.
I think when the pipeline system across France cost about 90 million dollars, and
The French are not taking care of it.
I don't know what they did.
I rendered my report to DOD and they haven't asked me to go back again.
I imagine they will one of these days ask me to go back again.
I was spent about two weeks looking at it.
Went to Donges, that's D-O-N-G-E-S on the channel, Channel Coast where the tankers unload and that unloading facility was in very bad shape too.
But a French hate a rich uncle.
That's their philosophy.
And I've had French people tell me that because a good friend of mine, an officer, married a French gal.
And we know him very well.
He's dead now.
But the French hate a rich uncle.
And we've seen it several times.
And it's particularly evident in Paris, a Parisian
expresses all of the bad things about the French psychology.
Now, the people out in the provinces are pretty good guys.
They're just good old country people.
But the haughty Parisians are despicable, really.
They really are despicable.
And the wife and I were over there last November.
Crime in Paris today is pitiful.
Oh, it's awful.
Subways.
The metro system, the beautiful subway they've got.
When you ride the Metro, by God, be sure you've got your billfold velcroed in your pocket or zippered in your pocket because of pickpockets.
We were targeted pickpockets on the Metro.

Three guys, three Algerian-looking students, dashed in on us and bumped into us and then went right out the door before the door closed at the Metro stop, at the Concord Metro stop, which is a very busy one.
Did they get your wallet?
No.
I had some jackets I wear, particularly overseas, with zippers in the inside coat pocket.
Put the wallet in there and close the zipper.
And there's all sorts of things now.
There's a little wallet thing you can put on your leg.
It's an elastic thing.
Slip it on over your sock.
You can put your wallet right down in it.
There's all sorts of things.
But the best thing, and you can put a flap on your pocket
on your inside coat pocket with Velcro.
And built that up.
But I've got two or three jackets with zippers in the inside pockets.
And that's perfect.
Now let's talk about McNamara and you helping set up the Defense Supply Agency.
What was the rationale for that?
Why did McNamara want that?
He wanted a joint facility, a joint activity, a joint agency
take care of the requirements of all the services, staffed by people from all the services, to avoid and save duplication of effort and duplication of activity and services.
Now what I'm going to say, you won't hear from a lot of military guys of any rank, but I think Bob McNamara is the only Secretary of Defense we ever had.

He was the only one with the vision and the courage and the guts to do some of these things, to do away with this absolutely foolish, wasteful, and scandalous self-service interest that some of my peers and colleagues in the military services hold out for their respective services.
We have gone too far.
Life is too complex.
Weapon systems are too expensive for petty service jealousies and rights to prevail.
We've got to have one central defense effort and activity staffed and manned by people of the various disciplines, Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, and to do away with the damn duplication of effort.
And a lot has happened since the start of this, but a hell of a lot more remains to be done.
You may have been reading recently about some of the battles in the Joint Chiefs of Staff where they want to make some changes.
And they've just got to do it because there are still some people that just hold out, you know, they say, well, hell, this is an Army role, this is an Army responsibility, and they ought to do it.
We ought to do it.
We the Army ought to do it.
A lot of guys in the Air Force say the same thing.
A lot of guys in the Navy.
I think the guys in the Navy and the Army are the worst so far as being jealous of their prerogatives and their roles and their missions.
I believe the Air Force are more joint-minded.
At least I found that from my experience.
McNamara wanted to do this because, for what I've said, he did it.
And I had the opportunity to help create it from the ground floor of this defense supply agency.
And he picked AT McNamara, General McNamara, to head the thing up.
And there was a nuclear service of about 12 officers.
that arrived in Washington.
We went to Temporary Building A down on Buzzard Point right adjacent to the Fort McNair there, a temporary building built in World War II.
And we were in there for about four months and putting the thing together organizationally and gathering people in from the services.
Then we moved over to Cameron Station over in Virginia and they rehabilitated offices for us.
We had all kinds of problems getting people from the services to help staff the organization.
The Army and a lot of the staff, you know, they would send us not the best guys, but some of their mediocre guys.
It's awful.
Why would they do that?
Because they were against it.
They were against it.
They were against it.
So the hierarchy, the Army Chief of Staff was against it.
And the people, we the people that served in the joint agencies suffered in our respective service because of our service in the joint staffs in the joint agencies.
But I'm proud and happy to have been a part of the beginning of joint defense efforts in this country because
The quicker we get to it in a clean, pure basis, the cheaper, the more bang we're going to get for the buck.
And it's just pitiful, really.
And was the function of the Defense Supply Agency to coordinate all of the supplies that are needed for all services?
Not only coordinate, but actually take control.
The inventory control, the procurement of them, the management of them, and then issue them out to the services based on what they've asked for.
Yeah, absolutely.
All the common supplies.
And then there was always a fight of whether the service would turn it over to the DSA because, oh, they said, no, we've got to manage this because this is peculiar to our missions.
And even though the Navy used the same thing, and the Air Force used the same thing, they said, no, we've got to manage this.
Well, it was a slow, painful process.
But gradually and gradually, we took away all of the things that were specifically jointly used things.
But you'd be surprised.
They would argue about things like mundane things, like underwear.
Oh, this particular type of underwear, this is peculiar to the Navy.
Even certain foodstuffs and everything, certain rations, operational rations.
How did you ever get over all that nonsense?
Well, McNamara issued, you know, certain, and the Secretary, he, the Secretary of Defense, and he had the backing of the White House, and...
It was painful, but it came about.
It came about, and it came about very quickly.
And, of course, they're still fighting today about a lot of things.
They're fighting today about a lot of things.
A lot of even weapon systems and certain vehicles.
They're fighting.
All the things they're fighting about today are the hard ones.
The easy ones and the not-so-hard ones that we've already...
put in joint operation.
Like all the uniforms?
All the uniforms, all the ammunition, and things like that.
There's, line item wise,
Probably close to six, seven, 800,000 different line items.
No kidding.
That are in joint supply now, yeah.
Where's the warehouse for this?
I suppose there's a number of warehouses.
There must be enormous.
Number of depots.
The largest ones are in Ogden, Utah, New Cumberland, Pennsylvania.
Anniston, Alabama.
Did you have to take these over from them?
Yeah, we took these over.
You took these over from the individual services?
Sure did.
They must have complained.
DSA depots, yeah.
All of this came about.
It's a massive thing.
Did you keep the original commanders in charge of those?
In most cases we did, yes.
Most cases.
But then the next commander went to a comparable officer from another service.
So an Air Force commander would go in and take over a Navy depot.
From a Navy depot, and then the next commander might be a guy from the Army, and his deputy might be a guy from the Navy or a guy from the Air Force.
Just like when I commanded the Defense Industrial Supply Center in northeast Philadelphia, it had been a Navy command.
It was responsible and is responsible now for all of the...
the fasteners, the bearings, the sheet steel, the sheet aluminum, the plate steel, the gaskets, and the bearings, I mentioned that, and the aircraft fasteners, and bolts and nuts.
It's responsible for about 400,000 line items.
And we had them stored in these DSA depots at about five locations around the country.
and everything was, all the requisitions are on a computer basis and distribution and shipping orders were on a computer basis.
And this was a real interesting operation, a real can of worms with all those different things.
We had in Northeast Philly at this old Naval Supply Depot headquarters, I had about 150 officers of all the services.
about 2,000 civilians and then scattered around in the procurement offices and about that many again.
And this was after I left the headquarters and they sent me out to run one of these joint activities.
Then I went from there down to southeast Philadelphia just for one end of Philadelphia the other to take over the personnel support center which is the largest one of the joint

supply centers because of its it's the largest one from a monetary standpoint because of other than from weapon systems because of food clothing medical organizational equipment and the like now you being in the groundwork here for the design supply
You must have irritated some of your superiors.
Oh, yes.
No question about it.
And that might be another reason why you didn't get that second star.

Well, it might have been, but I think everybody that had any interest in it is all satisfied it's because of the Eisenhower-George Gordon Moore incident and some of the residual feedback and results from that.
It could have been, could have been.
But did you irritate a lot of your superiors?
Yes, I'm sure I did.
I'm sure I did.
There's no question about it.
No question about it.
Even some of the people, well, in my own service army, because, you know, they would refer to you as a DSA type or a joint staff type.
And everybody suffered a little bit.
from it, from the services.
But that's gradually disappearing and now in my last command I have, the guy that took over from me was a Navy Admiral.
And then the guy that took over from him was an Air Force Major General.
And the guy that's there now is an Army Major General.
And on your
The only Brigadier to have that job.
Yes, I'm the only one that's had that job since 1967.
Yeah, since I left there.
I think you're right.
I think the record will show that.
This is, of course, one of McNamara's desires to centralize the whole system and streamline the whole system.
Streamline and centralize.
And it's sort of like setting up the Defense Intelligence Agency at the same time.
I had a good friend that was mixed up in that, and oh my God, the arguments they had about that.
You wouldn't believe it.
Do you know General Maples?
No.
No?
I sure didn't know him.
He was in on that, and he was also a... Have you had some guys say the same thing about this joint business?
It's pitiful.
It really is pitiful.
I think that the presidents have been derelict in their duty as commander-in-chief.
all of them that have happened since McNamara's time, for not sounding out and saying more publicly and in service debate and in service direction.
I think the people that have occupied the Oval Office and the White House could have done a hell of a lot to help speed this thing along.
Of course, it's come along a long, long way.
But there's still a long way to go and there's billions of dollars in the offing because the duplication of effort and the duplication of roles and missions, it's just scandalous, really.
Tell me about McNamara.
I liked the guy.
I really liked the guy.
What did you like about him?
You were one of the very first generals that I've interviewed who liked him.
Most of them say that he was very bright, but he was obnoxious and that he had no respect for the military.
Well, that's not true.
He did have respect for the military.
McNamara is a very, he's maybe a little bit cocky.
Most sharp, real sharp guys are when they achieve a lot of power.
Napoleon was.
Maybe McNamara is kind of like Napoleon in that respect, but McNamara has a lot of humility.
He has a lot of feeling and I got to know the guy.
I never saw him a whole lot, but he remembered who I was and he remembered certain things about things we had done.
He mentioned a couple of things one time about that was a great job you did on all those
directed orders and so forth.
Well, that was six months after that happened.
And he had courage, he had guts, and he was extremely bright.
He was really bright.
He was, of course, one of the original whiz kids, and you can spell it all with caps as far as he's concerned.
Extremely bright.
And I know that nearly everybody
Almost everybody doesn't like him.
But a lot of people do like him, and I just happen to be one that does.
Were you in a lot of meetings or some meetings with him?
Some, yes.
How did he handle them?
Very efficiently, very efficiently.
Right to the point, and he respected people's opinions.
He was not, you know, he didn't try to force his... Matter of fact, he kind of...
He was a pretty good proponent of the decision by committee type, you know?
Two or three people to handle a task problem and come up with a committee opinion or a joint opinion on it.
What did you think of the so-called whiz kids?
Did you have any dealings with those?
No, I didn't really.
I never was thrown in any contact with that group.
McNamara I guess was the only one.
But I think he did a great service to the United States, McNamara did.
And Kennedy was very astute to bring a guy like McNamara in.
Of course Kennedy and McNamara were very, very close.
Did you ever have any debates with some of your colleagues in the Army about this since you took such an opposite view of most of them that I've talked to?
Lots of them.
Lots of them.
What they say?
Well, they say about what you've heard that, you know, he's obnoxious and autocratic and so forth.
Nobody ever, ever discounted his ability.
Nobody ever discounted his ability.
And I say that the charter for the Secretary of Defense is very strong.
He can do just damn near anything if he has guts to do it.
And that's why I say McNamara is the only Secretary of Defense we ever had.
From what I've read, and I don't have any inside information, but what I've read, I think Caspar Weinberger is fairly close to performing much like McNamara did.
But the Secretary of Defense, with his charter, has got a hell of a lot of authority and a hell of a lot of power.
And McNamara was the only guy that used it, and I think he used it wisely.
And if he'd been there longer, we'd be further along.
I think we'd have a leaner, stronger defense posture.
Why don't we take a little walk through the plant?
Great, let's do that.
I was at a cocktail party, and he was telling a story about a serviceman that had had an accident, and the family had had a lot of hardship and everything, and the guy had tears in his eyes.
McNamara.
McNamara.
Tell me that.
A warrant officer.
He had spoken to the warrant officer's wife.
And the guy had a lot of compassion.
I just can't see them telling somebody that they don't know anything.
Well, let's continue about your next one, which was command of Defense Industrial Supply Center.
Yeah.
And was this one of McNamara's babies, too?
This is one of McNamara's babies.
He established about five of these joint
supply of service commands where they managed inventory.
You got it on?
Yes, I did.
Where they managed inventory for common items for all the services and procured for all the services.
They were jointly staffed and so forth.
And the chain of command was directly to the Secretary of Defense.
And we had no operational authority from our respective services.
It was all to the Office of the Secretary of Defense.
And of course, this sometimes worked to a disadvantage to the individual service officer and his relationship with his other service.
But those difficulties were really minimal, and I think they mainly
revolved around personnel administration matters primarily.
Could you give me an example of the type of things that you would order at the industrial supply?
Yeah, steel for the Navy shipyards and aluminum plate for the Air Force maintenance depots like at Kelly Field in Texas and at Wright-Patterson.
Barings for all sorts of purposes.

components for the nuclear submarines and for the repair and all kinds of aircraft fasteners, wing fasteners and aircraft fasteners and things, some common components to landing gears and things like that.
The peculiar items in an aircraft were supplied by the Aviation Supply Office, but the
the common things on an aircraft and there are many thousands of common items that can come from any place.
And I spent about a year at that command and we were very successful and very satisfying and a vacancy opened up at the Defense Personnel Support Center in South Philly.
Kind of an emergency vacancy because the then commander
who was also an army type, a major general army, had suffered a heart attack, and they wanted him replaced with the minimum of lag in operation and authority and so forth.
So they said, look, we're going to move you down across town to South Philadelphia to run DPSC.
And there was quarters on the facility down there, as well as we had quarters on our facility at the industrial supply center.
So, hell, we moved over a weekend.
We moved in and took right off.
And it was there that I found myself during the Vietnam buildup.
Prior to that, I had made an extensive TDY trip to Vietnam.
and spent about 60 days over there on some joint matters.
And then when I was at DPSC, I was sent over by the Secretary of Defense to make an exhaustive logistical survey of supply operations and logistic support of the forces in Southeast Asia.
And what did you find when you went over there?
When was that, 1966?
No, this was in, yeah, it was early 66.
A lot of problems, a lot of confusion, a lot of bad management.
Bad management attributed sorely to the lack of command attention to the problems, such as improper...
